abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project is rated marginally
            satisfactory. The policy development component was
            successful, the institutional strengthening component was
            partially successful, and the physical targets were achieved
            if not exceeded. These are among the lessons learned: Direct
            public sector investment in land development and housing
            finance is problematic in spite of mitigating measures such
            as technical assistance introduced into project design and
            conditionality. Formulation, adoption, and
            operationalization of new policies takes much longer than
            usually assumed by government and the Bank at appraisal
            although political will and determination on the part of
            government agencies eventually lead to success.
            Institutional strengthening programs also need more time,
            and sustained improvements in the performance of
            institutions take considerably longer than the average
            project implementation period. Bilateral assistance to
            finance technical assistance is preferred because it is
            usually on a grant basis to the government, and can be
            passed on, on the same terms. Strong management commitment
            to the project's objectives can bring about a reversal
            in poor implementation trends when it is brought to their
            attention that the project's target group is being
            missed. Good coordination and communications among
            cofinanciers can lend credence to policy advice, resulting
            in improved implementation and greater overall impact.
